abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            unsatisfactory, sustainability unlikely, while the
            institutional development impact is modest. Furthermore,
            both the Bank, and Borrower performances are rated
            unsatisfactory, given considerable difficulties during the
            period 1995-1997, triggered by the economic crisis, which
            prevented committed counterpart contributions - severely
            delaying implementation, thus inducing social problems,
            while unanticipated environmental impacts hampered results.
            A number of valuable lessons are drawn from the project,
            particularly relevant for large infrastructure projects
            involving resettlement, and environmental impacts. It would
            be advisable that Bank loans be allocated to finance high
            cost, critical project components, and, that given a
            shortage of Borrower's counterpart funds, these would
            be allocated to finance those components which are easier to
            procure, and less complex to implement. Such complexity,
            also requires coordination from central, and local agencies;
            unfortunately an overly optimistic view by the Bank on
            resettlement, and environmental issues, disregarded its
            political implications, which should have been dealt with at
            the early stages. Other lessons address failures in applying
            legal remedies; in appropriately addressing the
            project's bi-national nature at project design, and
            appraisal; in allowing early interventions of Bank senior
            management, given the potential, critical situation of the
            project; and, in envisaging the need for early enactment of
            expropriation laws to impound the reservoir.

repnme.cdata!:
Argentina and Paraguay - Yacyreta
            Hydroelectric Project : Review of Problems and Assessment of
            Action Plans

abstracts.cdata!:
The Review of Problems and Assessments
            of Action Plans for the Yacyreta Hydroelectric Project in
            Argentina and Paraguay examines problems presented by the
            Requesters in the Request for Inspection. The report
            assesses the adequacy of Action Plans that were implemented
            in regard to the Requests. The Review also addresses
            additional Requests for Inspections and the
            Management's comments on these Requests. The final part
            of the Review addresses the Bank's compliance with
            policies and procedures in regard to the Yacyreta
            Hydroelectric Project.

repnme.cdata!:
Argentina and Paraguay - Yacyreta
            Hydroelectric Project : Report and Recommendation of the
            Inspection Panel

abstracts.cdata!:
The Report and Recommendation of the
            Inspection Panel for the Yacyreta Hydroelectric Project in
            Argentina and Brazil outlines the concerns of the
            Requesters, an organization called Sobrevivenca,
            representing the people of Encarnacion, Paraguay.  The
            Requesters state that the environment and the standards of
            living have been compromised due to the filling of the
            reservoir for the hydroelectric project and that there was a
            lack of proper supervision in the environmental and
            resettlement activities. The Requesters allege that the
            filling of the reservoir caused the water to become to
            stagnant and polluted and contaminated the drinking water;
            affected sanitation in the area; destroyed crops; flooded
            farmlands; disrupted fish migration by damming the river.
            Social impacts included a loss of jobs, livelihood, and
            forced resettled to inadequate housing.  The Requesters also
            state that the Bank has been lax in their overall
            supervision of the project.  The Management Response replied
            to the claims, stating that the problems listed by the
            Requesters were not caused by the Bank's lack of
            supervision and that all environmental and resettlement
            activities had met certain criteria in order to be completed.
